posts.title: Back to School: K-12 Education Resources from the Jerome Robbins Dance Division
posts.text: Ideas to get your kids out of their chairs and engaging in active learning using our Digital Collections portal.

posts.title: Barnard Summer Interships: Junior Amelia Haynes Clears the Copyright for A Photo Collection to be Digitized
posts.text: Barnard rising junior, Amelia Haynes, a political science major, diligently investigated the photo collection of Lisa Miller to clear the copyright for digitization. Through this process, she learned about the larger relationship between the Dance Division and rightsholders.

posts.title: Barnard Summer Interships: Junior Maya Weiss Learns about Informal Education Practices in the Jerome Robbins Dance Division
posts.text: Barnard rising Junior, Maya Weiss, an architecture and dance double major, learned informal education theory to create a fixed education curriculum to be shared with students in the New York City public school system.

posts.title: Taking Chance Further by Preeti Vasudevan
posts.text: Dancer-choreographer Vasudevan tells of the fascinating connection observed between her contemporary work (and Indian background) and the work of Merce Cunningham.

posts.title: Picture This or That by Robert Greskovic
posts.text: The Jerome Robbins Dance Division Research Fellow examines the visual design elements of select works from dancer and choreographer, Merce Cunningham.

posts.title: Zen Principles Observed in Cunningham Technique and Their Practical Applications by Justin Tornow
posts.text: Dance practitioner, educator, and NYPL Research Fellow Justin Tornow discusses how groundbreaking choreographer Merce Cunningham integrated Zen principles into his work.

posts.title: Cunningham and Television in the Sixties by Claire Bishop
posts.text: While researching the work of Merce Cunningham, author and professor Claire Bishop discovered Cunningham's openness to new technology and keen interest in television, and the connection drawn between TV spectatorship and the decentralization of stage space.

posts.title: A Dancer's Life, Shaped by Jerome Robbins by Ellen Bar
posts.text: Former New York City Ballet dancer Ellen Bar recalls seeing her first Robbins ballet, bringing one to film, and then sharing dance with her young daughter.

posts.title: Geography Lessons by Amanda Vaill
posts.text: In anticipation of her upcoming book, "The World Opened Up: Selected Writings of Jerome Robbins," the bestselling author details her look into Robbins' life and work.

posts.title: Jerome Robbins at 100, and After, by Julia Foulkes
posts.text: Hear from the curator of the upcoming exhibit, "Voice of My City: Jerome Robbins and New York," on how she addressed the life of a brilliant and complicated artist.

posts.title: Using Visual Thinking Strategies in Dance Curriculum by Julie Lemberger
posts.text: A 2017-2018 Jerome Robbins Dance Research Fellow shares her experiences merging photography and dance to a group of third graders.

posts.title: Awakening of Humanity Within the Framework of Classicism by Adrian Danchig-Waring
posts.text: Adrian Danchig-Waring, principal dancer for the New York City Ballet and a 2017-2018 Jerome Robbins Dance Research Fellow, discusses Robbins, Balanchine, and philosophies of ballet.

posts.title: Robbins in Love With Chopin: "No Stories" By Robert Greskovic
posts.text: 49 years later, Robert Greskovic remembers the premiere of the ballet Dances at a Gathering—and the intricate details of its construction which lend to its timelessness.

posts.title: Jerome Robbins On Television by Gregory Victor
Fond Reminiscences of Jerome Robbins by William James Earle
posts.text: A good friend and frequent dinner guest of Jerome Robbins shares his thoughts on the world-famous choreographer's friends and good times (and love of the NYPL), in this guest post.

posts.title: An Emotional Archive: Hiie Saumaa on Jerome Robbins
posts.text: A Jerome Robbins Dance Research Fellow reflects on Robbins' life and archives, from a January 2018 symposium.

posts.title: Connected Choreography? Nijinsky's "Faune" & Robbins's "Faun"
posts.text: Alastair Macaulay, chief dance critic for The New York Times, investigates connections between Vaslav Nijinsky’s "L'Après-midi d'un Faune" and Jerome Robbins’s "Afternoon of a Faun."

posts.title: Sharing Dance Digitally: Understanding Issues of Copyright & Access
posts.text: Intern Lexa Armstrong shares what she learned while working in the Jerome Robbins Dance Division.

posts.title: Digital Footprints: Creating a Loie Fuller Database
posts.text: Intern Juliana DeVaan shares what she learned while working in the Jerome Robbins Dance Division.
